chapter.title: Average Number of Cycles in a Permutation

introduction.p:
Let A(n) be the average number of cycles in an n-permutation. The goal of this activity is to prove that
A(n) = \sum_{i=1}^n \frac{1}{i}.
Here, \displaystyle{H(n) = \sum_{i=1}^n \frac{1}{i}} is the nth Harmonic number, which is another very important sequence in mathematics.
Let c(n) denote the total number of cycles in all n-permutations.

li.p: Use a graph to explain why H(n) is a pretty good approximation for \int_1^n \frac{1}{x} dx. What function does this integral represent?

statement.p:
We will prove the recurrence
c(n) = n \cdot c(n-1) + (n-1)!
As usual, we will treat element n as special. Given an n-permutation f \in S_n, what happens when we remove element n? There are two cases
Suppose that n was in a cycle by itself. Prove that the total number of {\bf{cycles}} in such permutations is c(n-1) + (n-1)!.
Suppose that n was not in a cycle by itself. Prove that the total number of {\bf{cycles}} in such permutations is (n-1) \cdot c(n-1).
Putting together the answers from questions 2 and 3, we find that
c(n) = \Big( c(n-1) + (n-1)! \Big)+ (n-1) \cdot c(n-1) = n \cdot c(n-1) + (n-1)!
as claimed at the start of the problem.
\item[5.] \myname{The main result} Starting with the formula in problem 1(b) and the recurrence in problem 2, prove that
A(n) = \sum_{i=1}^n \frac{1}{i}.
